questions.question: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitations and shortness of breath for the past 2 hours. On examination, his pulse is irregularly irregular with a rate of 140 beats per minute. An ECG of the patient is given below. CHA2DS2-VASc score calculation shows a score of 3. Which of the following statements about his condition is FALSE?

options.A: The irregular pulse is due to abnormal atrial firing and re-entry circuits
options.B: The atrial rate is likely 300 beats per minute with a 2:1 AV block.
options.C: Anticoagulation is recommended to reduce stroke risk.
options.D: Beta-blockers and digoxin are the first-line rhythm and rate control agents respectively.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The atrial rate is likely 300 beats per minute with a 2:1 AV block. Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation such as palpitations, shortness of breath, irregularly irregular pulse and ECG findings like fibrillatory P waves, irregular QRS complexes are classic signs of atrial fibrillation (AF) . An atrial rate of 300 beats per minute with a 2:1 AV block is characteristic of atrial flutter , not atrial fibrillation. Atrial Fibrillation Features Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits. (Option A ruled out) Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke ECG Features QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves Ventricular Rate: Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min) Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue Fibrillation ECG features" data-author="PeaBrainC" data-hash="8584" data-license="CC BY SA 4.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Atrial_Fibrillation_in_two_leads.jpg" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/rhfXbf9ysZoOaagwaGY41744292691.png" /> Management Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD,

questions.question: A 68-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department in acute distress. He is diaphoretic, tachycardic, and complains of severe chest pain. His ECG is given below. Given the patient's condition, what is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Synchronized cardioversion Explanation: The patient's clinical presentation of acute distress, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and severe chest pain, along with the ECG showing saw-tooth flutter waves, is indicative of Takotsubo cardiomyopath with hemodynamic instability. This necessitates immediate synchronized cardioversion to restore normal sinus rhythm and stabilize his condition. Atrial Flutter Features Atrial flutter is characterized by a large re-entry circuit, usually within the right atrium, encircling the tricuspid annulus originating from the cavotricuspid isthmus. The atrial rate is approximately 300 beats per minute . It is typically associated with 2:1, 3:1, or 4:1 AV block, resulting in ventricular rates of 150, 100, or 75 beats per minute. ECG Features The ECG shows saw-tooth flutter waves , often referred to as "F-waves." With a 2:1 AV block, flutter waves may be buried in QRS complexes and T waves, making them difficult to identify. Diagnosis Atrial flutter should be suspected in narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of 150 beats per minute. Carotid sinus pressure or intravenous adenosine may help reveal flutter waves by temporarily increasing the degree of AV block. Management 1. Rhythm Control: Acute Management: Hemodynamically Unstable Patients: Synchronized cardioversion (Option D). Stable Patients: Electrical cardioversion (if no intracardiac thrombus). Pharmacological cardioversion: Antiarrhythmic drugs: Amiodarone (Option A ruled out) Class IA: Procainamide, Quinidine, Disopyramide Class IC: Flecainide, Propafenone Calcium Channel Blockers: Verapamil, Diltiazem Beta-Blockers: Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol Long-Term Management: Radiofrequency catheter ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus. (Option B ruled out) 2. Rate Control: First-Line Agents: Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil, Diltiazem) Beta-Blockers (e.g., Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol) Digoxin (use cautiously due to

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with fatigue, confusion, and muscle weakness. The ECG is attached below. Which of the following would be the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: the ECG finding of a shortened QT interval (Lead V3) strongly suggests hypercalcemia. The above ECG depicts a shortened QT interval QT Interval Abnormalities: Abnormality Causes ECG Findings Prolonged QT Interval Congenital Long QT Syndrome Acquired causes: - Electrolyte disturbances (hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia) (Option A and Option D ruled out) - Medications (antiarrhythmics, antipsychotics, antibiotics) - Bradycardia - Hypothyroidism (Option C ruled out) - Hypothermia - Myocardial ischemia QTc > 440 ms in males or > 460 ms in females T wave abnormalities (broad, notched, or low amplitude) Increased risk of Torsades de Pointes Shortened QT Interval Congenital Short QT Syndrome Acquired causes: - Hypercalcemia (Option B) - Hyperkalemia - Hyperthermia - Acidosis - Digoxin effect (not toxicity) - Increased sympathetic tone QTc < 330 ms Tall, peaked T waves Absent or very short ST segment Increased risk of atrial and ventricular arrhythmias QT Dispersion Myocardial ischemia or infarction Left ventricular hypertrophy Electrolyte imbalances Autonomic dysfunction Difference between the longest and shortest QT interval > 50 ms across all 12 leads Associated with increased risk of ventricular arrhythmias T Wave Alternans Severe heart disease Electrolyte imbalances Long QT syndrome Acute myocardial ischemia Beat-to-beat alternation in T wave amplitude, morphology, or polarity May be visible or microscopic (requiring special ECG processing) Associated with increased risk of sudden cardiac death Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6931435/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4291996/

questions.question: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with confusion and muscle weakness. His laboratory results show a serum potassium level of 7.2 mEq/L. Which of the following T-wave morphologies is most likely to be seen on this patient's ECG? A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: typically shows peaked/tall T-waves, which is represented in Option C. T-wave abnormalities: T-wave Abnormality Associated Conditions and Characteristics Peaked T-waves Hyperkalemia: Narrow, pointed, and tall T-waves Hyperacute phase of myocardial infarction: Broad-based, asymmetric T-waves Left ventricular hypertrophy: Tall T-waves in precordial leads Prinzmetal angina: Tall, pointed T-waves during chest pain Normal variant: Especially in V2-V4 in young patients and athletes Inverted T-waves Myocardial ischemia: Symmetrically inverted T-waves Wellens syndrome: Deeply inverted or biphasic T-waves in V2-V4 Cerebrovascular injury: Deep, symmetrically inverted T-waves (cerebral T-waves) Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Deep T-wave inversions in lateral precordial leads Pulmonary embolism: T-wave inversion in III, aVF (as part of S1Q3T3 pattern) Flattened T-waves Hypokalemia: Flattened T-waves, sometimes with prominent U waves Hypothyroidism: Low amplitude, flattened T-waves Digoxin effect: Flattened or inverted T-waves with 'scooped' ST segments Other T-wave changes Left bundle branch block: T-wave discordant to QRS complex Right bundle branch block: T-wave inversion in right precordial leads Acute pericarditis: T-wave inversion following ST-segment elevation Hypomagnesemia: Widened T-waves with flattened tops Flattened T-waves (Option A) are more commonly associated with hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia. Deeply inverted T-waves (Option B) are seen in conditions like myocardial ischemia or Wellens syndrome, not hyperkalemia. Biphasic T-waves (Option D) can be seen in Wellens syndrome or as a normal variant, but are not characteristic of hyperkalemia.

questions.question: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. His ECG is given below. Which of the following is NOT a common cause of changes seen in the ECG above?
questions.explanation: leads (II, III, AVF). This is a case of acute anterior wall infarction. Hypokalemia is typically associated with ST-segment depression , not elevation. Causes of ST-Segment Elevation and Depression ST elevation ST depression Acute myocardial infarction (Option A ruled out) Early repolarization (normal variant) Pericarditis (Option B ruled out) Left ventricular hypertrophy in V1–V3 leads (Option C ruled out) Left bundle branch block in V1–V3 leads. Ventricular aneurysm Myocardial ischemia Hypokalemia Digitalis effect Reciprocal changes in acute MI Left ventricular hypertrophy in V5, V6, I, aVL leads. Left bundle branch block in I, aVL, V5–V6 leads. Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459364/

questions.question: A 62-year-old man presents to the emergency department with palpitations and lightheadedness. His ECG shows a rapid, regular rhythm with a rate of 150 beats per minute as shown below Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with this ECG finding?
questions.explanation: regular rhythm with narrow QRS complexes and no discernible P waves - is consistent with a narrow QRS complex tachycardia . Narrow QRS complex tachycardia is associated with AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia or AV reentrant tachycardia (Orthodromic) . Note: Orthodromic: The Action Potential propagates in the physiological direction. Antidromic: The Action Potential propagates in the opposite direction to the physiological direction. Types of QRS Complex Abnormalities: Type of QRS Complex Associated Conditions Narrow QRS complex AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia, AV reentrant tachycardia (Orthodromic) Broad QRS complex Ventricular tachycardia, Torsades de Pointes Delta Wave Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome J wave/Osbourne wave Hypothermia Epsilon wave Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia Ventricular tachycardia (Option A) is associated with broad QRS complexes, not narrow ones as described in the question. Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome (Option C) is associated with a delta wave on ECG, which wasn't mentioned in the description. While it can cause a type of narrow complex tachycardia (orthodromic AVRT), it's not the most likely diagnosis based on the information given. Hypothermia (Option D) is associated with J waves (Osbourne waves) on ECG, which were not described in the question. It also doesn't typically cause tachycardia. Reference: Davidson’s Principle and Practice of Medicine Edition 24th Page 473, 474, 475 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1501063/

questions.question: Match the following tachyarrhythmias with their most appropriate initial treatment: Tachyarrhythmia Treatment Atrial Fibrillation A. Intravenous Adenosine Stable Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia B. Synchronized Cardioversion Torsades de Pointes C. Intravenous Magnesium Sulfate Supraventricular Tachycardia (AVNRT) D. Intravenous Amiodarone
questions.explanation: Atrial fibrillation Esmolol/ Ibutilide Atrial flutter Esmolol/ Ibutilide AV nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT)/PSVT Prevention: Verapamil Unstable: Adenosine Wolff Parkinson White (WPW) syndrome Prevention: Flecainide Drug of choice: Procainamide Ventricular tachycardia Post MI: Lignocaine Stable: Amiodarone Ventricular bigeminy Lignocaine Torsades de Pointes (TDP) Magnesium sulphate Reference: Goldberger’s Clinical Electrocardiography, A Simplified Approach, 9th Edition, Page. 139, 154, 167.

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with palpitations and lightheadedness. She has a history of hypertension and is on multiple medications. Her ECG is given below: Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Torsades de Pointes (TdP) , a specific form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia occurring in the setting of QT interval prolongation. Intravenous magnesium sulfate is the first-line treatment for TdP, as it helps suppress the triggering PVCs and can shorten the QT interval. Torsades de Pointes: ECG features : Polymorphic VT : Characterized by variation in QRS direction and amplitude. Spindle-shaped pattern : The QRS complexes form a twisting or spindle-shaped "envelope." Prolonged QT interval PVC initiation : Often triggered by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC) on a prolonged T-U wave, creating an "R on T" phenomenon. Postectopic pause : A pause following the PVC, further prolonging repolarization. Causes : Mnemonic: "A TIGERS BITE" A - Antiarrhythmics (Class IA and III) T - Tricyclic antidepressants I - Ischemia (myocardial) G - Genetics (congenital long QT syndrome) E - Electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia) R - Restrictive cardiomyopathy S - Stroke (especially subarachnoid hemorrhage) B - Bradycardia I - Interactions (drug-drug interactions that prolong QT) T - Toxins (organophosphates, arsenic, etc.) E - Endocrine disorders (hypothyroidism, pheochromocytoma) Treatment : Immediate management: Intravenous magnesium sulfate (even if serum magnesium is normal) Discontinue potential QT-prolonging medications Correct electrolyte abnormalities, especially hypokalemia Consider temporary pacing or isoproterenol infusion to increase heart rate and shorten QT interval Amiodarone (Option A) should be avoided as it can further prolong the QT interval. Immediate electrical cardioversion (Option B) is usually reserved for hemodynamically unstable patients. Oral beta-blockers (Option D) are not the immediate management, although they may be considered later in the treatment course.

questions.question: A 65-year-old male with a history of prior myocardial infarction presents to the emergency department with severe palpitations, dizziness, and chest pain. His blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, and he appears diaphoretic and confused. An ECG shows wide QRS complexes, a regular rhythm, and a ventricular rate of 160 bpm. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: ventricular tachycardia (VT) as indicated by the wide QRS complexes, regular rhythm, and associated symptoms (hypotension, chest pain, altered mental status). Hemodynamic instability in VT requires immediate synchronized cardioversion , which delivers a shock timed with the R wave to avoid precipitating ventricular fibrillation (VF). Ventricular tachycardia Pathology: VT is defined as three or more consecutive premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) with a heart rate of over 100 bpm. It can be either monomorphic (all QRS complexes appear similar) or polymorphic (QRS complexes vary in shape). Monomorphic VT is often related to a reentry circuit around a myocardial scar, typically after myocardial infarction, while polymorphic VT, especially Torsades de Pointes, is related to prolonged QT intervals, ischemia, or electrolyte imbalances. ECG Findings: Monomorphic VT : Wide QRS complexes (>120 ms), regular rhythm, and consistent morphology across leads. The QRS axis may vary depending on the site of origin (e.g., LBBB or RBBB-like morphology). Polymorphic VT : Continuously changing QRS morphology, often associated with prolonged QT intervals (in Torsades de Pointes). Treatment: Stable Monomorphic VT : Intravenous procainamide or amiodarone can be used. (Option D ruled out) Unstable Monomorphic VT : Immediate synchronized cardioversion is required. (Option C ruled out) Polymorphic VT (Torsades de Pointes) : IV magnesium sulfate and correction of underlying electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hypokalemia) are crucial, along with discontinuation of QT-prolonging drugs. (Option B ruled out)

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome: WPW syndrome is characterized by the presence of an accessory pathway between the atria and ventricles. The classic ECG findings in WPW syndrome include a prolonged PR interval, delta waves, and narrow QRS complexes. Orthodromic AVRT in WPW syndrome always presents with a wide QRS complex tachycardia. A premature ventricular complex (PVC) can initiate AVRT in patients with WPW syndrome. Which of the following options correctly identifies the true statements?
questions.explanation: the presence of an abnormal accessory electrical pathway between the atria and ventricles, bypassing the AV node (Statement I). This accessory pathway, also known as the Bundle of Kent, allows for premature ventricular activation during sinus rhythm, resulting in characteristic ECG findings: Short PR interval (<120 ms) due to rapid conduction through the accessory pathway Delta wave: a slurred upstroke of the QRS complex Widened QRS complex (>110 ms) due to the fusion of early (preexcited) and normal ventricular activation Fig: ECG in WPW Syndrome A premature ventricular complex (PVC) occurring close to the ventricular entrance of the accessory pathway can initiate AVRT in patients with WPW syndrome (Statement IV). Atrioventricular Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT) AVRT is a type of supraventricular tachycardia that occurs in patients with an accessory pathway, such as in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. Pathology: AVRT involves a reentrant circuit that includes the normal AV conduction system and the accessory pathway. Two types exist: Orthodromic AVRT (more common): Conduction travels down the AV node and up the accessory pathway. Antidromic AVRT (less common): Conduction travels down the accessory pathway and up the AV node. ECG Features: Orthodromic AVRT: Narrow QRS complex tachycardia (QRS < 120 ms) (Statement III ruled out) Regular rhythm with heart rates typically 150-250 bpm Retrograde P waves often visible in the ST segment or early T wave Antidromic AVRT: Wide QRS complex tachycardia (QRS > 120 ms) Regular rhythm with heart rates typically 170-240 bpm Retrograde P waves may be obscured by the wide QRS AVRT can be initiated by premature atrial or ventricular complexes that block one pathway and conduct through the other, setting up the reentrant circuit.

questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents with sudden onset palpitations. ECG is taken and given below. It shows a narrow complex tachycardia at 180 bpm. The postgraduate successfully terminates the arrhythmia using the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following best describes the primary mechanism by which this maneuver terminates the arrhythmia?

options.A: Direct stimulation of the sinoatrial node
options.B: Increased sympathetic tone to the heart
options.C: Transient block in AV node conduction

questions.explanation: increases intrathoracic pressure. This leads to a reflex increase in vagal tone (parasympathetic activity). Increased vagal tone affects the AV node, potentially causing a transient block in conduction. Effect on the arrhythmia: Many supraventricular tachycardias involve a reentry circuit that includes the AV node. A transient block in AV node conduction can disrupt this circuit. This disruption can terminate the tachyarrhythmia, often restoring normal sinus rhythm. carotid sinus massage" data-author="Chokkalingam Mani, Bhalaghuru & Pavri, Behzad." data-hash="8548" data-license="CC BY 2.5" data-source="https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Typical-AVNRT- terminated-by-carotid-sinus-massage-The-RP-interval-is-short-less-than_fig3_260091968" data-tags="April2025" height="297" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/2HZx4SeWcWUf1mf4QsTg1744291505.png" width="642" /> Fig: Typical AVNRT terminated by carotid sinus massage Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT): Signs and Symptoms: Sudden onset of rapid, regular palpitations Dizziness or lightheadedness Shortness of breath Chest discomfort or pressure Anxiety Fatigue In severe cases: syncope, hypotension, or heart failure symptoms ECG Findings: Regular, narrow-complex tachycardia (QRS duration <120 ms) Reduced R-R interval Heart rate between 150-250 bpm P waves often not visible or buried in T waves Supraventricular Tachycardia ECG findings" data-author="James Heilman, MD" data-hash="8551" data-license="OPEN ACCESS" data-source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supraventricular_tachycardia#" data-tags="April2025" height="280" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/RLEObUJblbq3Y9MXCcy91744291613.png" width="576" /> Common

questions.question: A 50-year-old man comes to your clinic for a routine check-up. He has no significant past history, exercises regularly, and reports no chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and his pulse rate is 75 beats per minute and regular. You perform an ECG as part of the screening, shown below. What is the most likely finding based on this ECG?
questions.explanation: and Size P wave Atrial depolarization is initiated by the SA node. 0.08–0.11 seconds 2–2.75 small boxes <2.5 mm (0.25 mV) in amplitude/ height <0.12 sec (120 msec or 3 small boxes) in width PR interval Time from onset of atrial depolarization (P wave) to onset of ventricular depolarization (electrical impulse passing through AV node) 0.12–0.20 seconds 3–5 small boxes Q wave Initial depolarization of the interventricular septum, directed from left to right. <0.04 seconds <1 small box Depth: <1/4 of R wave or ~1–2 mm (<0.5 small boxes) QRS complex Ventricular depolarization - the time taken for the electrical impulse to spread through the ventricles. <0.10 seconds <2.5 small boxes in width Height: 5–30 mm (1–6 big boxes) QT interval Time from the start of ventricular depolarization to the end of ventricular repolarization. Duration depends on HR. HR inversely proportional QT length. Rate-corrected (QTc) 330–350 msec ~11 small boxes ST segment Represents the early part of ventricular repolarization. It is isoelectric (flat). 0.08–0.12 seconds 2–3 small boxes Normally isoelectric (flat), deviations >1 small box indicate pathology T wave Represents the later stage of ventricular repolarization. <0.04 seconds 2.5–6.25 small boxes Height: Varies. Normally <5 mm (1 big box) in limb leads, <10 mm (2 big boxes) in precordial leads U wave Unknown origin; possibly related to repolarization of Purkinje fibers or ventricular walls. Not always measurable Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) (Option A) presents with larger-than-normal QRS voltages, especially in the precordial leads (V1–V6), and may show left axis deviation. This ECG shows normal QRS amplitude, ruling out LVH. First-degree AV block (Option C) is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds). Since the PR interval is normal (0.16 seconds), a first-degree AV block is not present. Right bundle branch block (RBBB) (Option D) is identified by a prolonged QRS duration (>0.12 seconds) with an "M-shaped" QRS in leads V1 and V2. This ECG shows a normal QRS duration, so RBBB is

questions.question: A 70-year-old patient is diagnosed with severe bradycardia and is scheduled for a pacemaker implantation. The electrophysiologist is evaluating different types of artificial pacemakers. Where are the leads of the single-lead and dual-lead pacemakers placed in the heart?

options.A: Single-lead: Right ventricle; Dual-lead: Right atrium and right ventricle
options.B: Single-lead: Right atrium; Dual-lead: Right ventricle and left ventricle
options.C: Single-lead: Left ventricle; Dual-lead: Right atrium and left ventricle
options.D: Single-lead: Right ventricle; Dual-lead: Left ventricle and right ventricle

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Single-lead: Right ventricle; Dual-lead: Right atrium and right ventricle has leads in the right atrium and right ventricle. Pacemakers of the Heart: Natural Pacemaker sites and their depolarization rates: Sinoatrial node: 60 to 100 beats per minute Atria: less than 60 beats per minute Atrioventricular node: 40 to 60 beats per minute Ventricles: 20 to 40 beats per minute Artificial Pacemaker: An artificial pacemaker is a small battery-operated device that helps regulate the heart's rhythm by producing electrical impulses. It typically consists of three parts: a generator, leads (wires), and sensors (electrodes). Traditional pacemakers are implanted under the skin, usually on the chest just below the collarbone or in the stomach area, and they connect to the heart through tiny wires. There are several types of traditional pacemakers: Single-lead pacemakers: One lead is placed in the right ventricle. Dual-lead pacemakers: One lead is placed in the right atrium and one in the right ventricle. Biventricular pacemakers (CRT): Three leads are used, placed in the right atrium, right ventricle, and left ventricle. Wireless pacemakers are smaller and consist of a pulse generator and electrodes in one device. They are implanted inside the heart through a catheter inserted via internal jugular or femoral or subclavian vein, sending impulses to the right ventricle without the need for traditional surgery.

questions.question: A 74-year-old patient comes to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent dizziness and lightheadedness. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed, as shown below. Based on the ECG findings and the clinical scenario, what type of atrioventricular block is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2:1 AV block (Type II - Infranodal) Explanation: 2:1 AV Block (Type II - Infranodal) is identified by the presence of every other P wave not followed by a QRS complex (As seen in the ECG), with a normal PR interval and a prolonged QRS complex. This pattern confirms the Type II block, which typically indicates a conduction defect in the His-Purkinje system. 2:1 Atrioventricular Block About 2:1 AV block occurs when every other P wave is not conducted to the ventricles, resulting in missed QRS complexes. It can arise from either the AV node (nodal) or the His-Purkinje system (infranodal). Types Nodal (Type I - Wenckebach): Results from impaired conduction in the AV node, which can be influenced by sympathetic and parasympathetic tone. Characterized by progressively prolonged PR intervals before a dropped beat; usually benign. Infranodal Block (Type II): Indicates a conduction defect in the His-Purkinje system, where interventions affecting the AV node will not alter the block. It is less affected by autonomic interventions. PR interval remains normal with a dropped beat; often requires a permanent pacemaker. ECG Features Every other P wave is not followed by a QRS complex. In Type I, the PR interval is progressively prolonged, and the QRS complex is narrow. In Type II, the PR interval is normal, and the QRS complex is prolonged. A narrow QRS with Type I suggests AV nodal block, while a wide QRS indicates infranodal involvement. Diagnostic Maneuvers Carotid Sinus Massage/Adenosine: Slows the sinus rate, potentially unmasking PR interval changes indicative of Type I. Atropine Administration: Enhances AV conduction; can resolve Type I block. Exercise Testing: Also enhances AV conduction, potentially eliminating Type I block. Treatment Type II block typically requires implantation of a permanent pacemaker. In cases of His-Purkinje disease, atropine may worsen the degree of block. 2:1 AV Block (Type I - Wenckebach) (Option A): This type is characterized by progressively lengthening PR intervals before a dropped beat. In this case, the PR interval is normal, and there is no evidence of progressive prolongation, ruling out Type I. First-Degree AV Block (Option C): First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) but maintains a consistent relationship between P waves and QRS complexes. In this scenario, there is a lack of consistent conduction, making first-degree block unlikely. Third-Degree AV Block (Option D): This condition shows complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, with no correlation between the two. While there are

questions.question: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe fatigue, dizziness, and episodes of syncope. His medical history includes hypertension and a prior myocardial infarction. ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Intravenous atropine Explanation: Based on the symptoms of severe fatigue, dizziness, syncope, and the ECG findings of complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes, the diagnosis is a third-degree atrioventricular block. The initial management for third-degree AV block may include intravenous atropine to attempt to increase heart rate, but it is often ineffective in this condition. Third-Degree Atrioventricular Block Pathology Complete loss of communication between the atria and ventricles. SA node activity continues independently, but impulses do not reach the ventricles. Atrial and ventricular activities are completely dissociated. Etiology Common causes include idiopathic fibrosis, structural heart disease, acute ischemia, medication toxicity, and post-surgical effects. Associated conditions: Lyme disease, collagen vascular disorders, and myocardial infarction (especially inferior wall MI). Risk factors include diabetes, hypertension, and prior cardiovascular diseases. Clinical Features Symptoms may include fatigue, chest pain, shortness of breath, and syncope. Patients often exhibit bradycardia and may show signs of hemodynamic instability. Physical exam may reveal cannon A-waves due to simultaneous atrial and ventricular contractions. ECG Features Characterized by complete atrioventricular dissociation. The atrial rate is faster than the ventricular rate. ECG shows independent P waves and QRS complexes with no relationship between them. P-P interval and R-R interval is constant but there is no synchrony between P-R. Atrioventricular Block ECG features" data-author="James Heilman, MD" data-hash="8599" data-license="CC BY SA 3.0" data-source="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third-degree_atrioventricular_block" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/D6nk8lt9Rq1xAHWpLGoA1744293577.png" /> Treatment Initial management may include intravenous atropine . Patients typically require pacing, either temporary (transcutaneous or transvenous) or permanent pacemaker placement. Urgent consultation with cardiology and electrophysiology is

questions.question: A 68-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of fatigue and occasional lightheadedness. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. During the examination, he describes episodes of near-syncope. The physician performs an ECG to evaluate his symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Mobitz Type II Explanation: In Mobitz Type II second-degree AV block, there is a consistent PR interval followed by a non-conducted P wave, leading to dropped beats. This type is often associated with structural heart disease and can progress to complete heart block, which aligns with the patient’s symptoms and history. Second-degree AV block: Second-degree AV block is characterized by a delay in conduction between the atria and ventricles, leading to a prolonged PR interval. Two types exist: Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach) and Mobitz Type II. Aspect Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach) Mobitz Type II Pathology Progressive prolongation of PR interval until dropped beat. PR interval longest before dropped beat. Constant PR interval until a P wave is not followed by a QRS complex. Etiology Normal variant; high vagal tone; inferior ischemia; medication toxicity; post-surgery. Associated with structural heart disease; myocardial ischemia; fibrosis. Clinical Features Often asymptomatic; May cause syncope or lightheadedness. Symptoms include fatigue, dyspnea, chest pain; Can progress to complete heart block. ECG Features PR interval progressively lengthens before a dropped beat . Constant PR interval; May have widened QRS complex. Treatment Usually no treatment needed; may use atropine if symptomatic. Requires immediate pacing; often necessitates a permanent pacemaker. First-Degree AV Block (Option A) It is characterized by a consistently prolonged PR interval (greater than 200 ms) but with every P wave conducted to the ventricles. There are no dropped beats, and the relationship between the P waves and QRS complexes remains intact. While the PR interval may be prolonged in this case, the presence of a dropped QRS complex indicates a higher degree of block, making this option incorrect for the given ECG findings. Mobitz Type I (Option B): In Mobitz Type I, there is a progressive lengthening of the PR interval until a QRS complex is

questions.question: A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has a history of mild hypertension, which is well-controlled with medication. She reports no symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, or chest pain. An ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) First-Degree AV Block Explanation: The ECG shows a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) but consistently conducts P waves to QRS complexes, indicating first-degree AV block. There are no dropped beats, ruling out higher-degree blocks. First Degree AV Block Pathology First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) without disruption of conduction from atria to ventricles. The delay typically occurs in the AV node, but may also involve the atria, His bundle, or Purkinje fibers. Etiology Commonly attributed to increased vagal tone in younger patients. In older patients, often due to fibrotic changes in the cardiac conduction system. Other causes include coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, electrolyte abnormalities, inflammation, infections, certain drugs, infiltrative diseases, collagen vascular diseases, and idiopathic degenerative diseases. Lymes disease, Chagas disease, Diphtheria, Rheumatoid arthritis, Scleroderma. Clinical Features Usually asymptomatic; patients are often unaware of the condition until discovered on an ECG. In cases where the PR interval exceeds 0.30 seconds, symptoms may resemble "pacemaker syndrome," including dyspnea, malaise, lightheadedness, and chest pain. ECG Features Diagnosis is confirmed by a PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds on an ECG. PR interval can be marked (>0.30 seconds) in some cases, and P waves may appear within preceding T waves. Treatment Generally, no treatment is required; routine observation is sufficient. Pacemaker placement may be considered for symptomatic patients with PR interval >0.30 seconds or those with coexisting heart disease. No antiarrhythmic medications are indicated, and surveillance with routine ECGs is recommended to monitor for worsening. Second-Degree AV Block (Option A): This block features progressive lengthening of the PR interval followed by a dropped QRS complex, which is absent in this ECG as there are no dropped beats. Third-Degree AV Block (Option C): Here, here is complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes. This is absent in the ECG since P waves are consistently followed by QRS complexes. Bundle Branch

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with recurrent palpitations and dizziness. An ECG of the patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's diagnosis?

options.A: He is at risk for pre-excited atrial fibrillation leading to dangerously fast ventricular rates
options.B: The accessory pathway is the Bundle of James, facilitating rapid conduction.
options.C: The ECG shows a short PR interval, normal QRS, and no delta wave
options.D: Adenosine is contraindicated in this condition

questions.explanation: ventricular rates Correct Answer: A) He is at risk for pre-excited atrial fibrillation leading to dangerously fast ventricular rates. Explanation: The diagnosis is Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome , characterized by recurrent palpitations and dizziness due to an accessory pathway causing abnormal conduction. The ECG typically shows a short PR interval, wide QRS complex, and a delta wave, indicating pre-excitation of the ventricles. In WPW Syndrome, the presence of an accessory pathway can lead to pre-excited atrial fibrillation, which poses a significant risk of very rapid ventricular rates, potentially leading to syncope or other complications. Aspect Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome Lown-Ganong-Levine (LGL) Syndrome Pathology Accessory pathways (APs) known as the Bundle of Kent are the abnormal tissue bands connecting the atria and ventricles. (Option B ruled out) They allow conduction outside the AV node, either antegrade or retrograde (in concealed APs), bypassing the normal AV conduction system. Present from birth, they result from incomplete partitioning of the atrium and ventricle by the fibrous AV rings. Associated with Ebstein’s anomaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, PRKAG2 mutations, Danon’s disease, and Fabry’s disease. Accessory pathway connects to ventricular myocardium. LGL is a type of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) characterized by a short PR interval and a normal QRS duration. It involves an accessory pathway called the Bundle of James that allows rapid conduction between the atria and ventricles, often linked to the atrioventricular (AV) node. Accessory pathway bypasses the normal pathway and connects to BOH. Clinical Features Common arrhythmias include narrow-complex paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), wide-complex tachycardias, and rarely, sudden death. Tachycardia may develop due to re-entry circuits, causing orthodromic or antidromic AV re-entry tachycardias (AVRT). Pre-excited atrial fibrillation (AF) can occur, leading to a dangerously fast ventricular rate, syncope, or collapse, requiring urgent treatment. Patients may experience episodes of palpitations, dizziness, or

questions.question: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department with palpitations and lightheadedness. He has no significant past medical history and is otherwise healthy. After a thorough examination, an ECG is obtained. Based on the patient’s presentation and the findings of the ECG, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome Explanation: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is a type of pre-excitation syndrome caused by an accessory pathway (the Bundle of Kent) that allows electrical impulses to bypass the normal conduction system of the heart. This can lead to a characteristic presentation, including symptoms like palpitations, lightheadedness, and potentially syncope. The presence of a short PR interval and a delta wave on the ECG indicates ventricular pre-excitation, typical of WPW syndrome. This condition can predispose individuals to tachyarrhythmias. PR Interval : The PR interval measures the time from the beginning of the P wave (atrial depolarization) to the beginning of the QRS complex (ventricular depolarization). Normal PR Interval Range: 0.12 to 0.20 seconds (120 to 200 milliseconds). A normal PR interval indicates proper conduction through the AV node. Short PR Interval A PR interval of less than 0.12 seconds (120 milliseconds). Associated Conditions: Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome: Characterized by a short PR interval, wide QRS complex, and delta wave, indicating ventricular pre-excitation due to an accessory pathway. Ectopic Pacemaker Activity: A short PR interval with retrograde P waves (negative in lead II) suggests an ectopic pacemaker from the atria or AV junction. Atrial Fibrillation: No PR interval is present due to chaotic atrial depolarization. Atrial Flutter: A standard PR interval is absent due to continuous, rapid flutter waves instead of distinct P waves. These flutter waves occur at rates of 250–350 beats per minute, creating a "sawtooth" ECG pattern. The AV node conducts only some impulses (e.g., 2:1 or 4:1), leading to an organized ventricular response but without a conventional PR interval. Atrial fibrillation (AF) (Option A) is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm and the absence of distinct P waves on the ECG. While patients with WPW syndrome can develop atrial fibrillation, the question describes a patient with palpitations and a more stable rhythm pattern,

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman presents with progressive fatigue, palpitations, and mild dyspnea on exertion. She has a known history of a congenital heart condition diagnosed in childhood but has not had regular follow-ups. On examination, there is a prominent jugular venous pulse and a soft systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. A 12-lead ECG was done and it is given below. What is the most likely cause of the abnormal P waves on her ECG?
questions.explanation: characterized by the Downward placement of tricuspid valves leading to atrialization of the Right ventricle and right atrial enlargement. In this condition, the right atrium can become significantly dilated, causing the P waves on the ECG to appear broad and tall. The given shows the findings of broad and tall P waves along with a prolonged PR interval and a right bundle branch block pattern. This presentation aligns well with the patient's symptoms of fatigue and palpitations and is supported by the examination findings of jugular venous distention. P Wave in ECG: Feature Normal P Wave Right Atrial Enlargement ( P Pulmonale ) Left Atrial Enlargement ( P Mitrale ) Cause Normal atrial depolarization Pulmonary disease Congenital heart disease Tricuspid valve disorders Mitral valve disease Left ventricular failure Amplitude < 2.5 mm > 2.5 mm (in leads II, III, aVF, sometimes V1) May be increased but less prominent than in RAA Duration < 0.12 sec (120 ms) Normal (< 0.12 sec) Prolonged > 0.12 sec (broad P wave) Shape Smooth, upright Tall, peaked, narrow Notched/bifid ("M"-shaped) in lead II Lead II Appearance Smooth and positive Tall, peaked P wave Notched/bifid P wave Lead V1 Appearance Biphasic (small negative) Deep P wave Biphasic with prominent, prolonged negative terminal Hyperkalemia (Option B) , or elevated potassium levels, can cause changes in the ECG, resulting in peaked T waves, widened QRS complexes , and potentially a flattening or disappearance of the P waves . The presence of broad and tall P waves in this patient

questions.question: A 60-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with a one-month history of mild exertional dyspnea. She denies chest pain but has noticed some occasional palpitations. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and regular heart sounds. You order an ECG, which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.explanation: is NEGATIVE (dominant S wave) in leads II, III and aVF QRS Axis: This refers to the mean orientation of the QRS vector in the frontal plane, which determines how electrical activity flows through the heart. Normal Axis : QRS axis between -30° and +90°, points downward and slightly left. Abnormal Axis Deviations: Left Axis Deviation : QRS axis less than -30°. Right Axis Deviation : QRS axis greater than +90°. Extreme Axis Deviation : QRS axis between -90° and 180°. Normal QRS Axis: (Option A ruled out) Ranges from -30° to +100° . Variations within this range are considered normal. On ECG, this shows a positive QRS complex in both lead I and aVF. Left Axis Deviation (LAD): Defined when the QRS axis is more negative than -30°. Tall R wave in lead I, deep S wave in the lead III, and biphasic RS complex in lead II (with the S wave deeper than the R wave). Common causes: Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) Left anterior fascicular block (left anterior hemiblock) Inferior myocardial infarction (MI) It can also occur as a normal variant. Right Axis Deviation (RAD): (Option B ruled out) Defined when the QRS axis is more positive than +90° to +100° . R wave in lead III is taller than lead II, RS complex in lead I (S wave deeper than R wave), and tall R waves in inferior leads (II, III, aVF). Common causes: Right ventricular overload (acute or chronic) Lateral myocardial infarction Left posterior fascicular block Dextrocardia Left pneumothorax Electrode misplacement (reversal of left and right arm electrodes) May occur as a normal variant, especially in children and young adults. Lead Normal Axis Left Axis Deviation (LAD) Right Axis Deviation (RAD) Lead I Positive (R wave > S wave) Positive (R wave > S wave) Negative (S wave > R wave) Lead II Positive (R wave > S wave) Negative (S wave > R wave) Positive (R wave > S wave) Lead III Positive (R
